BatteryBot will be completely closed, and you won\'t see it in your status bar any more.\n
\nIf you just want to leave the main window and keep the indicator running, press Cancel and then just press your device\'s BACK button to leave the main window.

Cloudocog will completely close, together with all running services.\n \nIf you just want to leave the main window and keep services running, press Cancel and then just press your device\'s BACK button to leave the main window.

Warning: Changing this setting (both enabling and disabling it) will reset your color settings.\n
\nIf you have a Motorola Droid, Droid X, Droid 2, Defy, or Samsung Moment, you should turn this on when you first get the app, and then leave it alone. All other devices, as far as I know, should always leave this off.
File successfully written to root of SD card.

This is BatteryBot Pro, the \"Pro\" version of the popular free app, BatteryBot. It\'s available for purchase from the Android Market, but it\'s an open source project, which means you can download the source for free from the project website.

This is BatteryBot, the free version of theBatteryBot family of apps. It\'s available from the Android Market, and it\'s an open source project, which means you can download the source for free from the project website.\n
\nPlease consider donating by upgrading to thePro Version.

BatteryBot Pro is a lightweight battery indicator for the Androidâ¢ mobile operating system. Its core feature is that it provides an icon that lives in the status bar and shows you the percentage of battery charge left.


This Pro version offers a great deal more utility than that, however. Besides offering red, amber, and green icons, it also has the following key features as of version 3.0:


â¢ Fully automated estimated charge/discharge time left. 
â¢ Downloadable icon plugins. 
â¢ Logging of battery state. 
â¢ Manually disable/reenable the device lock screen, with the option to automatically disable it when plugged in and reenable it when unplugged. 
â¢ Many more useful things that you'll discover throughout.

BatteryBot is a lightweight battery indicator for the Androidâ¢ mobile operating system. Its core feature is that it provides an icon that lives in the status bar and shows you the percentage of battery charge left.


The Pro version offers a great deal more utility than that, however. Besides offering red, amber, and green icons, it also has the following key features as of version 3.0:


â¢ Fully automated estimated charge/discharge time left. 
â¢ Downloadable icon plugins. 
â¢ Logging of battery state. 
â¢ Manually disable/reenable the device lock screen, with the option to automatically disable it when plugged in and reenable it when unplugged. 
â¢ Many more useful things that you'll discover throughout.

(These are out of my control.)


â¢ There's no way to remove the built-in battery icon. 
â¢ The notification icon in the status bar and the message you see in the notification tray are tied together â you can't have one without the other. 
â¢ Many apps should allow installation to removable storage (SD card); some should not. BatteryBot is of the latter group. Seethe project FAQ if you'd like further explanation.

â¢ Small, simple, and easy to read. 
â¢ It doesn't do any polling. It receives a broadcast message from the OS when the battery status changes, then it simply updates the icon and goes back to sleep. What this means is that it will take up a small amount of RAM, but essentially 0 CPU cycles, so it can't drain your battery. I estimate that it will cost you about 1 minute of usage time off of a full discharge as a worst case scenario. If you are experiencing anything worse than that, you probably have another app (such as a "task killer" app of some kind) interfering with BatteryBot's normal operation. 
â¢ Easy access to Battery Use screen (requires Android 1.6+). 
â¢ Configure to always start on boot, never start on boot, or start on boot if the app was running on shutdown. 
â¢ Lots more that I'm either forgetting or seem too minor to mention on their on, but that add up to a great app. 
â¢ The satisfaction of supporting the developer. (I really appreciate it!)

This software is distributed in the hope that it will be useful, but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.\n
\nWhile I do my best to make sure that it works well and does not cause problems, I am not responsible for any damage or inconvenience it may cause under any circumstance.

This app would only be available in English without the generous assistance of the volunteer translators. Thanks!


Many thanks are due to Google and all of the open-source coders who made the Android platform and this app possible.


The launcher icon (the upright battery you see in the Market) is based on an icon from the Oxygen icon theme and used under theCreative Common Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 License.

I need help translating this app to other languages. If you would like to help, please send me an email. (This address is only for translation; see Contact section below for all other inquiries.) Unless you prefer me not to, I will add your name to this section in acknowledgment of your assistance.
If you have a question or a problem, pleaseemail me.\n

The settings are organized into separate pages, as described below. Each page has its own help page describing the settings on that page. Simply press MENU then Help (on tablets, MENU isn\'t necessary) to get help from whatever settings page you are on.
You can configure which content to show in the pull-down notification and control its appearance.
You can select which icon set to use and change the settings for the icon set (e.g., colors).
Configure the feature to disable the lock screen
You can configure several aspects about the feature to automatically or manually disable your device\'s lock screen.
You can have BatteryBot notify you when your battery level reaches a certain point (e.g., the battery becomes fully charged, the battery level drops below 20%).
All other settings are on this page, including logging, lock screen, temperature unit, autostart, and more.
The Pro version has many more settings and features, including colorful icons, alarms, battery state logging, auto/manual lock screen disable, charge/discharge remaining estimates, and more.
Use system notification layout rather than custom BatteryBot layout?

If enabled, the system notification layout will be used instead of BatteryBot\'s custom layout. The system layout is less customizable, but a small minority of devices don\'t report default colors properly, making the custom layout ugly or hard to read. Other devices use an unusual layout, making the custom layout not fit in. Selecting this option will ensure that the notification will look like any other notification.\n
\nNote that this will result in having the status bar icon used in the notification.
Choose what you wish to see at the left end of the notification in the icon area. You can have just the battery graphic, just the textual charge percentage, or both, in either order.

Configure what goes in the top line of the notification: estimated time remaining (configurable elsewhere), how long since the status has changed (plugged in, unplugged, or fully charged), or the battery vital signs (battery health, temperature, and voltage).
You have the same options for the bottom line as for the top line.

Devices come in all shapes and sizes, so most translations need to use abbreviations to ensure that the time-remaining estimate fits comfortably in the notification area. If it still doesn\'t fit, you can opt for the condensed format. If you have plenty of room, you might prefer the verbose setting.
Include Time Since Status Change in Vital Signs?
If set, the vital signs line will also include the number of hours since the device became unplugged, plugged in, or fully charged.

You can override the colors for the notification text if the defaults are hard to read or if you just prefer something different. You can also choose to override whether or not to show a box around the icon area.
Show background color box in icon area?

On Jelly Bean and up (Android 4.1 and over), notifications can have a priority set. The effect(s) of changing the priority are not guaranteed, but in general:


â¢ Setting it to "Minimum" should in most cases remove the status bar icon but still show the notification in the pull-down notification tray.


â¢ Setting it to "Low" should allow other notifications, such as new email, to appear above the BatteryBot notification. This is nice in cases like email where the notification is expandable (expandable notifications are automatically expanded when they are the top notification).


Priorities "Default" and above seem to usually leave BatteryBot as the top notification, but I imagine there are edge cases where the higher priorities make a difference.


Again, the exact behavior may vary between devices and is not guaranteed.
Set the priority of the main notification. Alarms, plugins, and any other notifications are not affected by this setting, but they may in the future have configurable priority.

Android comes in many flavors, so there is no one perfect icon set that works well on every device. Pro users can use plugins to get more options, but there are now three built-in icon sets that should provide at least one good option for virtually every device.


"Classic" is the original icon set from 2009. It is still the best on older devices, but newer versions of Android (starting with Android 3.0, Honeycomb) shrink and dim the notification icons, making this set very difficult to read.


"Plain number" is the default for all newer Android devices. It is a very large white number that shows up well even after being shrunk and dimmed. It shows a lightning bolt under the number during charging.


"Smaller number" is like "Plain number" but smaller, because some newer devices do not actually shrink the icon like stock Android does, and the very large number in "Plain Number" can appear comically large on these devices.


If you have any BatteryBot Pro icon plugins installed (press MENU, then Get Plugins to get free plugins, or just press the Get Plugins button on the Action Bar on newer devices), you can choose among them here.
Alter icon to indicate when charging?
Some icon sets indicate when the battery is being charged, for example by showing a lightning bolt below the number. Disable this setting if you would prefer it not to do that.
If enabled, BatteryBot will log battery state changes.
If logging is enabled, then whenever you plug in your device, logs older than this will be deleted.

Android allows apps to disable and reenable what it calls the \"keyguard\", which you probably think of as the lock screen. Beyond simply disabling and reenabling it, however, there is no more control â I can\'t control which keys turn the screen on, for example.
Indicate when lock screen is disabled?
If checked, a separate notification will be shown indicating when the app is disabling the lock screen.
Confirm when manually disabling lock screen?

If checked, a confirmation dialog will pop up when you try to manually disable the lock screen. This is primarily intended to prevent new users from accidentally disabling their lock screen without knowing it. If you disable the lock screen with any regularity, you\'ll probably want to turn this off.
Exit main window immediately after dis/reenabling?

If you\'re someone for whom every keystroke (or touchscreen press) matters, you\'ll probably want to enable this. If your goal is to simply disable or reenable the lock screen and then get back to what you\'re doing, this keeps you from having to press the BACK key. Just pull down the notification bar, press on BatteryBot, and press the button to toggle the lock screen: three screen presses and you\'re back to what you were doing.\n
\nFor obvious reasons, you can only enable this if the previous setting is disabled, and vice versa.
Disable the lock screen when charging?

If checked, then whenever the device is plugged in, BatteryBot with disable the lock screen, and whenever the device is unplugged, it will enable it again.\n
\nNote that with this option enabled, you will still have to manually pass through the lock screen once before it will be auto-disabled.
Disallow use of the disable lock screen button?
If you have an alternative lock screen that allows access to the notification tray when the screen is locked, you might want to enabled this option for security reasons.
Show time since status changed rather than estimate of time remaining?

Enable this setting if you\'d prefer the main notification to show the time since the status changed (e.g., \"Unplugged for 5 hours\") rather than the estimate of time remaining. Both pieces of information are available from the main window.
Exit main window immediately after launching Battery Use?

If you\'re someone for whom every keystroke (or touchscreen press) matters, you might want to enable this. Enabling this preserves the old behavior of closing BatteryBot\'s main window immediately after launching the Battery Use screen.
Android reports the battery temperature in degrees Celsius. If you prefer to see the battery temperature in degrees Fahrenheit, check this option, and the app will convert for you.

Controls whether BatteryBot should start itself automatically when the device boots up.\n
\nThe \"If Running on Shutdown\" option works with regard to whether you\'ve most recently manually started or stopped BatteryBot. So if you kill BatteryBot through some other means, like a task killer, then BatteryBot doesn\'t know you stopped it, and it will still start at boot up if you have it set to this.
If the translation to your language is incomplete or inaccurate and you would prefer another, possibly better translation, you may choose to do so here.

In order to keep the binary package for BatteryBot reasonably small, there are some limitations for the colors. At the time of writing, you can have a red icon as high as 30%, an amber icon as high as 50%, and a green icon as low as 20%. I think these are reasonable compromises that should work for 99% of users.\n
\nTo give you maximum control, the colors can be turned on or off independently. This means that you can have as much as a four-tiered color scheme, where the icon is green when it is very full, then grayscale, then amber, then red. Of course, most people probably have the amber and green thresholds set to the same value, so that the icon is never grayscale.

The color preview will hopefully make it really easy to visualize what effect your color settings will have.\n
\nThis doesn\'t exist in 10% mode, because it just wouldn\'t make sense.
Use red icon when charge is low?
Whether or not to use a red icon below the specified threshold.
Red icon below what charge percentage:
Red icon at or below what charge percentage:

Specifies the charge level which the icon should turn red below (or at, in 10% Mode).


The options for the red threshold include all the values (in multiples of 5) for which there are red icons available.


In 10% Mode, things work slightly differently but should be self-explanatory.
Use amber icon when charge is medium?
Whether or not to use an amber icon below the specified threshold.
Amber icon below what charge percentage:
Amber icon at or below what charge percentage:

Specifies the charge level which the icon should turn amber below (or at, in 10% Mode).


The options for the amber threshold include all the values (in multiples of 5) for which there are amber icons available, starting 5 percentage points above the red threshold (if there is one). For example, if you have the red threshold set to 15, then your lowest option here will be 20.


In 10% Mode, things work slightly differently but should be self-explanatory.
Use green icon when charge is high?
Whether or not to use a green icon at or above the specified threshold.
Green icon at or above what charge percentage:

Specifies the charge level which the icon should be green at or above.


The options for the green threshold include all the values (in multiples of 5) for which there are green icons available, starting at the highest active threshold you have set for red or amber. For example, if you have the amber threshold set to 40, then your lowest option here will be 40.


In 10% Mode, things work slightly differently but should be self-explanatory.

Note: Checking or unchecking this will reset your icon color settings!


This setting cleans up the Icon Color settings to make more sense on devices that only show their charge level in 10% increments. According to user reports, that includes these devices:


â¢ Motorola Droid (original) 
â¢ Motorola Droid X 
â¢ Motorola Droid 2 
â¢ Motorola Defy 
â¢ Samsung Moment


As far as I'm aware, all other devices report every 1%, and so should not turn this on.

This page allows you to add new alarms, quickly enable or disable existing alarms, or delete alarms.


To add a new alarm, press "Add alarm" â this will create a new alarm and take you to the alarm settings page, where you can control the settings for the new alarm. See the help on that page for more details.


Below the "Add alarm" button is a list of any alarms you have created.


â¢ To edit an existing alarm, just press it. 
â¢ To delete an alarm, long-press it, then select "Delete Alarm". (You can also delete an alarm from the individual alarm settings page by pressing MENU then "Delete Alarm".) 
â¢ To quickly toggle whether an alarm is enabled, press the alarm clock icon to the left of the alarm text. (You can also enable or disable an alarm from the individual alarm settings page.)
If you want to temporarily disable an alarm without having to recreate it when you want it again, you can turn it off and on either here or on the main alarms page.
This is where you can control what conditions trigger the alarm.

There are currently five types of alarm that you can choose from.


The "Becomes fully charged" alarm will notify you when the status of your battery changes from "Charging" to "Fully Charged". Note that on many devices, this isn't necessarily the same thing as being at 100% charge.


The charge and temperature alarms require you to set a threshold below, after choosing that alarm type.


The "Health Fails" alarm will notify you if your battery health becomes something other than "Unknown" or "Good Health", as reported by Android.
Not used for this alarm type
For charge and temperature alarms, you need to set the temperature or charge level that will trigger the alarm.
This is where you can control various aspects of the alarm notification that is created to notify you when an alarm has been triggered.
Here you can control which sound to play when the alarm is triggered. Select \'Silent\' if you don\'t want a sound to be played.

If all goes well, setting this option will make the device vibrate when the alarm is triggered, unless the device is in Silent Mode, unless you have the device set up to vibrate even in Silent Mode. In other words, it should do what you expect. Please email me if something goes astray.

Sets whether the notification should enable the device\'s default lights. This generally flashes an LED or trackball. Note that every Android device I\'ve used has been slightly buggy in this department. If you have this checked, then the notification will request Android to flash lights, but it might not always actually happen.
